utterances: Now this is at a time when there are travel advisory against Kenya, where westerners have been discouraged from visiting.
But westerners are still coming.
And they've come, in large part, to see what has been called the Eight Wonder of the World, which is the great migration of the wildebeest.
In fact, now, June, July and August, a million wildebeests are expected to come from Tanzania into Kenya to grace for a few months and then head right back on home.
Gwen, thanks so much for joining us.
Thank you, Farai.
NPR Africa correspondent Gwen Thompkins joined us from Nairobi.
OK, a little more history now - George H.W.
Bush was born in Massachusetts the son of a Wall Street investment banker who would go on to be a U.S.
senator.
Bush went to the best schools.
He served his country at war, and as president, he became known as a pragmatist who could compromise.
He was, in other words, very much a symbol of a different kind of Republican Party.
And the years he served as president were years in which the GOP itself was changing.
Here to talk about that change is NPR lead political editor Domenico Montanaro.
Hey, Domenico.
Hey there, Mary Louise.
So I have been struck reading all the obituaries and remembrances by how often throughout his career and public life Bush seemed to find himself in disagreement with his own party.
Walk us through some of that.
Yeah, you know, look; first of all, this was someone who was chairman of the Republican National Committee during Watergate.
So he was very much a political player.
When Ronald Reagan came on the scene, he was leading a movement, one that really believed that government was the problem and in this orthodoxy of tax cuts.
When running against Reagan, though, you know, George H.W.
Bush...
This is 1980 for the...
...Presidential nomination.
...For the Republican presidential nomination, he disagreed with that policy.
And he referred to it this way.

What I call a voodoo economic policy.
Right, voodoo economic policy, which is something that he wound up having to back away from when he became Reagan's vice president.
As you do, yeah.
Well, I mean - and it was a very curious way he did it.
At one point in 1982, Bush claimed that he'd actually never said it.
Of course he had, and the news outlets had the tapes to show it.
And it was part of his transition that became complete in 1988 at the Republican National Convention during his acceptance speech when he famously said this.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
Read my lips - no new taxes.
(CHEERING, APPLAUSE)
Of course, Domenico, he then found that pledge was...
Yeah.
...A hard one to keep.
Was he - I mean, I wonder.
Was this his personal evolution, or was he trying to keep pace with where the country was going or where the party was going or what?
Well, look; he was a pragmatist.
He wanted to win.
Remember; this is a political guy, and he knew he needed that GOP base - sound familiar, right?
Yeah.

You know, obviously, when the Bailout Bill failed yesterday, people were saying like this really is a horrible thing.
Then the talk this morning, Madeleine, is well you know what?
Maybe we really don't - look, first of all we are going to get some kind of bailout.
And maybe the first bill wasn't so good after all.
And I think that's what's making the market go up.
Now, can we get there without doing anything?
I think the answer is no, because we're already doing something.
We, being the government, that is.
And number two, there has to be some sort of relief.
I wonder why we simply can't have relief go directly to mortgage holders, which is to say, average American families who hold mortgages.
Yeah, that was one objection that a lot of lawmakers had for voting against this, that there wasn't enough for the homeowner, for the average American.
Right.
And the thing is, is if you bailed out homeowners directly - I mean, if the whole problem, the underlying problem is the mortgage market, which it is.
Then if we sort of shore up that market, then wouldn't it ripple through the system in the same way that bad mortgages rippled through the system previously.
So if the mortgage market was fixed, then would all these financial products heal themselves, if you'll pardon the expression, and the banks get relief that way too.

And I said it's a category and set of seven things that everyone knows.
